title: Markets in the Making of Multilateral Military Interventions (4MI): International Organizations and Private Military and Security Companies
abstractText:
What are the potential implications of the collaboration between international organisations and Private Military and Security Companies (PMSCs), ie companies that provide military and security services for profit, in international military interventions?

This project analyses the contracting of PMSCs by the United Nations (UN), the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the European Union (EU) in three international military operations:

  1. the UN operation MONUC/MONUSCO in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DR Congo)
  2. the NATO ISAF mission in Afghanistan
  3. the EU mission ALTHEA in Bosnia-Herzegovina.

By comparing the regulatory, operational and representational practices of the UN, NATO, the EU and their security contractors with regards to the provision of military and security services in these three operations, the project aims to identify which practices may have a negative impact on the achievement of mission objectives and which may be considered examples of ‘best practice’ which may be used as policy guidance for these and other organisations, companies and operations. Such guidance is particularly important as the use of PMSCs in multilateral interventions is likely to increase due to reductions in the national armed forces and military budgets of many UN, NATO and EU member states.
